The crane, part of the construction process, represents change and rebuilding, yet it moves with a kind of grace that the speaker finds almost foreign or detached from their personal experience of loss. The phrase “in its own language” suggests that the crane, and by extension the world of construction and progress, operates outside of the emotional world of the speaker, almost indifferent to their grief.
